text: [Music]
cloud gaming let's people play the
latest video games without needing a
computer or console without even having
to buy discs or download games instead
the software is run on servers at huge
data centers with the footage stream to
your TV or phone aiming this way means
you never have to upgrade your equipment
the games can be run on much more
powerful Hardware over in the data
center and you never have to download
and install a software update ever again
analysts predict this could be the next
frontier in gaming cloud gaming was
worth three hundred and eighty seven
million dollars in 2018 where they
predict it could be worth 2.5 billion
dollars by 2023 there are some downsides
to cloud gaming you need a pretty fast
internet connection to stream the games
in high definition and also it's not an
all-you-can-eat buffet like with movie
streaming services you still have to buy
some of the games on top of your
subscription and not every game is
available on every service then there's
the question of game ownership what
happens if a cloud service closes down
will you lose access to your games at
least if you buy a disc you know you can
keep it in the attic or you can sell it
when you're finished with it Google says
it's stadia service will launch in
November and Microsoft has showed off
its cloud gaming service at this year's
e3 Sony has offered a cloud gaming
service for a few years with PlayStation
now but it still makes more than twice
as much money selling discs and
downloads than it does from its gaming
subscription services Sony has already
said it's working on the PlayStation 5
and at e3 Microsoft announced project
scarlet a new console for 2020 so while
cloud gaming services look to shake up
the industry it seems that consoles are
here to stay at least for now
